regretList.regret: I had an affair - worst mistake of my life. Now I always have to live with how awful I was to my husband. Instead of just being real and telling him how unhappy I was, I decided to do something so incredibly stupid that I'm not sure I can ever forgive myself.

Not taking the time to do some little things with my kids when they popped up because I was "too busy".
Letting my teenagers have unfettered access to their iPhones.
I regret letting a relationship (ok, and a bit of fear), stop me from moving to a new city to start my career out of college.

As I look back, I am struggling to find things I necessarily regret more a reflection of how I have grown and how my perspective has changed. If I could go back knowing what I know now, would I make different decisions, most definitely. But, you can only make decisions based on where you are. More recent, I came across a young couple at a Post Office needing to buy postage after hours and the machine required a credit card. When they asked, I said I didn't have my wallet on me. Which was true, but what I didn't say was that my wallet was in my vehicle. Right away I wished I had not said that, and went back with my wallet to purchase their postage. It was around 2 dollars. I did not take the cash they offered. I probably had $20 to $30 cash in my wallet, and what I regret is that I didn't think to offer it to them. It has been a good month since, and I still kick myself for not thinking to offer the cash. I feel as though it was their money, that I was just holding it for them.
I regret not furthering my education in order to have a better paying job..    And because of that I often worked two jobs and would have rather had more time with my children.
I regret not having made a higher bid for some apartments in Miami beach about 15-20 years ago.
I regret spending most of my 20's trying to prepare for the future instead of enjoying the moments I was in. I should've taken the chances that are so much harder to take now as I approach 50.
Taking on too much debt when I was younger. Poor financial decisions on home buying, and financing things I should have saved for and bought in cash.

Can't say I really have regrets.  Yes, maybe I would have liked some things to be different but I realize that all of the experiences have helped mold me into who I am today, and all have been helpful to my personal growth. At the time I made those decisions to act or not act, I was doing the best I could with the information I had.  No regrets.
I regret I have not made more efforts to make real friendships with a diverse set of people.
wasting so much time
sometimes not being brave enough when it comes to changes in bad situations and having it in my own hands

1 A failed first marriage
2 not managed to connect my second wife well with my mother
Sometimes I don't think enough about the consequences that will resolve in doing/saying something especially with neighbors who are different in being and thinking but you have to live with...

(1) Not travelling to Poland to meet the Dad of my wife before he died. (Actually he just died this Monday)
(2) Not staying in the USA and bring the love of my life to the USA. Instead I returned to Europe. Never know how that would have turned out.

I felt that I need a new challenge in my professional career. In 2018 work sucked and I was feeling really depressed, however I did not dare to change job. My loan on the house, 2 kids and wife kept me from changing something. But things got even worse, I stayed on the job and 2019 became a complete desaster. I regret that I did not have the courage to change company in 2018 and then finally got pushed out in 2019.
Wrong Marriage
Dort judge in good or Bad, take it and enjoy it
Not being more understanding of my parents and their troubles when I was a child.
Failing to make the most of higher education
I regret I did not have the courage to end a relationship when it should have ended.  Now we are old, and it's too late.  That said, there are certain pluses to the situation, even as it's difficult.
Have the courage to quit my cushy job when I was not learning or growing

I regret not making finding a life partner a priority. Work was always a priority instead of fostering relationships. 

I regret that I didn’t travel more. Especially now with the pandemic , now that I have more time and money, ironically I can’t travel.

While lucky, I regret not traveling more when I was young. I had a chance to live with a friend in another country when I was 25, but was afraid of how that would look on my resume, so I turned down that opportunity.
I wish I was taller.
Wish I had taken more smarter risks early in my career
I regret being ruled by low-level fear. Fear of trying something new. Fear of failing. Fear of the unknown...
2nd marriage

One significant regret I have is my choosing the safe path in education and career where I could go to the best schools and get an easy job in my career.  Instead, I wish that I had pursued science and medicine, a path where I would have had to work much harder and possibly not have only success as I worked towards my one-time goal of being a medical doctor.

Not finding my 12-step program sooner. Note that part of the promises from 12-step programs says “We will not regret the past nor wish to shut the door on it. We will comprehend the word serenity and we will know peace.”
Not pushing myself to experience more things in my teens and early 20s. In hindsight, the potential mistakes would have cost a lot less than I thought.

I wish I'd stood up for my own value in my marriage a lot sooner than I ended up doing so, and maybe we'd have been able to fix it with fewer years of built up patterns, disappointment and capitulation.
I regret a misplaced sense of obligation to a professional commitment that resulted in me not taking a job that would have provided me a secure and interesting career.
That I didn't set aside differences with loved ones sooner - pattern was established early to cut off family I saw as having wronged me in some way and I lost out as a result.

My husband and I had planned to have a big family, but after two daughters we couldn't fathom it. So we stopped. But I'll always wonder who that third child might have been, and how are lives would have been different if we'd had him/her.
That I took to heart other people's fears about what I said I wanted to pursue going into college and post-college.
It was a selfish act and wished I didn’t have to do it or had more understanding of the action I’ve done.
I wish I’d worked overseas when I was young. I was in too much of a hurry to get married.

I regret not being younger when I was younger, meaning I regret taking life so seriously when I was positioned to take more risks and have more fun. I try to live more "in the moment" these days, but realize I squandered so much of my youth not doing that!

When I was 19 I left college and was about to move to Austin TX to play music but instead moved to Carmel, NY. Everything that has happened since revolved around that random and sudden decision. I don't regret it so much as wonder what would have happened if we had gone the other route. My life might have turned out completely differently.
I regret being a meanie in 6th grade. I called a girl fat and hid from younger children I was supposed to be walking to school.
Not working harder in high school

Being afraid of change. Fear of the unknown has weighed in too heavily on many of my life's decisions. I have rationalized decisions I have made, when really the reason for not traveling more, changing careers, moving houses....is fear of change.
I regret that I got my girlfriend pregnant when I was 22, then married her because it was the right thing to do.

I had my mom up to be with me the weekend before Mother's Day because my sister who I was not getting along with was supposed to have her the next weekend. She didn't show up. Her aides told me she was alone and I didn't go down to be with her. She died the next week.

After graduation from Cornell I did not understand the financial setbacks I would face going into hospitality operations. I went in and had a hard time getting out—- working an extreme amount of hours for little compensation which has set me back for years.
I wish I had thought more about a career that would have allowed me to be a mother and have something for myself after the kids were grown.

I had two professors in in college who had a major impact on my career in the field of education.After graduating from college,I choose not to go back to see them and tell them how valuable their guidance was to my career.Now,major regret on my part.
I regret not spending more time with my dad in the month before he died.
I wish that I had called my dad on the phone more often while he was alive.
Having more fun in college
Sorry no regrets!

Abby was my first pet as a young adult, and I had had no experience with handling the closing days of a beloved pet's life. When she contracted cancer after I'd had her for more than ten years, I took her to the vet regularly and she was treated with everything they had -- but in the end it was not enough. People told me I "would know when it was time" to let her go, and that she "would tell me." And I just wanted her to stay with me forever, of course. So I waited TOO long, waiting for that mysterious message from her. And on one final terrible night I rushed her to the vet, but not in time to allow her to pass peacefully. She had a seizure in the car and died in my arms. I will always regret waiting too long to give my dear Abby a peaceful passing. After our years of happiness together, she deserved better from me. I still think about it and cry sometimes.
Not learning to fly a helicopter.
I regret not buying a house when I had the resources to do so.
I regret not realizing earlier that my son has ADHD, and instead yelling at him and calling him lazy.
I regret that I didn't use my words more to teach our children.  I did model my beliefs and values faithfully in our home.

It's hard to use the term regret. To regret is in reference to the past regarding some belief, decision or action. The thing is that at the time you made the decision you relying on the knowledge, experience and information available to you at the time you made the decision. In that sense having regrets is being hard or unfair to yourself. You did the  best  you could with what you had. That's all you can ask for.
That I didn't spend more time on spiritual development in my 20s and 30s.
After having spent 2 years building 3 failed startups, I regret quitting my well-paid job.
Not moving out of a city and job that I am with right now since last 15 years. Same city, same job.

Wish I'd not rushed to give my dog the prescribed antibiotic that caused rupture and death. Wish due to lockdown I'd not dithered or taken to new place nearby that only made money off us and didn't help. Wish I'd stayed calm and left well enough alone
Not showing up completely to the tasks as a student

Regrets are part of life. We all have something we wish we had done differently — or some action we wish we had taken or not taken. 

Please look back on your life for a moment. Then describe in 1 or 2 sentences one significant regret you have.
too many regreat

I regret feeling too much and expressing too little. Caught up in the basic survival and financial issues, I never focused on my personal life and the quality of my relationships. Chose work like an aspirin for my loneliness and kept living in the bubble, while the person I loved and deeply cared for was slowly fading away from the picture. He moved on quick, and I've been stuck for over a year where I was. Keeping your emotions bottled up hardly ever helps. Not being vulnerable early on is something I deeply regret. Trying to be self sufficient, and tough all the time has pushed me to a stage where I long for tenderness, only to find myself all alone.
Not writing / creating more

Most often chose the safe and practical options in life rather than those that really attracted me... whether in terms of choosing career options, or jobs, or relationships; Would have liked to take some more risks.
Nothing in life is worth regretting!
Trusting someone despite evidence to the contrary.
I wish that I had taken extra time on business trips to explore places visited.

Years ago in the window of an art gallery I saw a pair of ceramic candlesticks with three ducks heads sticking out of the top of each. They made me laugh and made me happy. But they were $75, and I didn't want to spend that money on something so frivolous. The regret continues to this day -- but I have never again refused to spend money on something that makes me (or those I love) happy.
Not applying for universities in California.
Not dating one of my high school friends who would have been my first boyfriend.
Staying in a toxic relationship too long
So far, that I haven't participated in public life to change forces that oppress women.
I regret putting so much importance on high school achievements that were set up merely for college.
I decided to help a talented person's project despite right away feeling poorly treated by the person. In retrospect, what seemed like the path of least resistance ended up being a terrible choice.
Not trying harder. Taking the wrong advice.
Having an affair.
Following society norms and my family's views vs. thinking things through myself.
I regret not going to law school as a young woman.

I wish I had learned to study and then applied it to my school work over the entirety of my school career. It seems so small but I think it would have made things so much easier. BTW, I am a college grad and it's all fine, but what a wasted opportunity.
Spending too much time on things that were insignificant and not focusing on real passion.
Not taking a job in another city because of a person who I thought I was in one with at the time
test this thing.
Poor attention level I gave to my first marriage.

I did not believe that I was worthy of a partner. I left people (ended relationships) first, because I thought the people closest to me would leave me if I "failed" in one way or another. So, I worked and worked. I wanted to prove I could be successful and worthy of friendship and love. I thought that I had made hundreds of friends, but I had developed very few deep and meaningful relationships outside of work.
Getting married to someone who I felt wasn't right for me, but did it because everyone else in my circle was married.
Not dating women.
I didn't date or make enough friends in high school or college. I began my adult life with an immature perspective towards relationships.

I regret I didn't contact the love of my life in 1963 and sort things out right away. He married someone else and so did I. I could have cleared things up at any point over the years. I didn't. He died. I never set the record straight. It feels like unfinished business. I likely would have married him or not. I'll never know. It's maddening if I allow myself to think about it.
Go to college after high school instead of getting married at 20 yrs old and taking ~15 years to get my bachelor's degree.
I regret being too afraid to make certain decisions- like moving to a big city or taking on big challenges and choosing the safe route.
I regret that I did not stay in therapy when I was in my twenties. I regret that I did not have a sit down open conversation with my sister before she died.

Not listening to friends, family members, and a counselor who all, in ways subtle or direct, warned me not to get together with a man who was courting me, but was very ill suited for me. I got into a very bad relationship that lasted years, was difficult to get out of, and took years to bounce back from.

My greatest regret is taking my sweet husband of 23 years for granted. I regret prioritizing my work over making memories  with him, assuming I’d have our retirement years to make it up to him, planning to treat him like a king. He died 6 weeks after I retired.

I regret I had know how to break out of my ignorance and family’s silence to ask my parents, especially my mother, about her/their families. I lost the chance at 23 when my mother died. I knew almost nothing even about her let alone grandparents, cousins, aunts & uncles. Trying to piece together any family history is incredibly difficult almost 50 years later.

I regret not being more present in my younger years. While I have definitive memories, I also know I would have had more if I knew how to pay attention as I do now. Participating more fully in school, reaching out to others more instead of being fearful of rejection.
Not going to grad school before having kids

I regret being a mean girl in grade school. It set me up for loneliness through my younger years. I put a tough front around me that no one could hurt me when I was miserable and so lonely on the inside.

After getting my PhD I had my choice of two post-doctoral fellowship programs, one at the CDC to be an Epidemic Intelligence Service (EIS) Officer and one at the National Cancer Institute. I picked NCI for reasons that seemed good at the time, but was never able to get a job at the CDC or in the government public health service. My career has sort of been mediocre and it can largely be traced to that one incorrect choice 20 years ago.

I avoided what I thought would be an uncomfortable conversation with my best friend.  I thought I could just ignore things and eventually all would be well.  In the end, it eroded the relationship and then when we had a conversation 2 years later, it was too late to truly fix what had gone wrong.  We are now more acquaintances, rather than best friends. I lost something very precious by not addressing a simple misunderstanding early on.
Not listening to my intuition when getting involved with people who caused me harm.
Not buying a house in Washington DC back in the mid-2000s! I didn’t realize I would be priced out of my city and that it was actually affordable back then.
Not completing graduate business school after a two year commitment of time & money.

1/ Turned down a very challenging but interesting job offer.
2/ Messed a little up with my education.
I'm not graduating from university
I regret not pursuing a professional basketball career. I should have worked more on my post moves and made the league.
Using money (aka student loans) to establish a sense of well-being, worthiness, acceptability, and inclusion.
Lack of assertiveness
Never finishing high school
Dropping out of college to get married, and never attaining my bachelor's degree.
I regret putting my wife through a separation early in our marriage.
I regret that I got in a flirtatious relationship with a coworker. We were both married.
I wonder if I should have made a career change.
I didn’t finish my college degree, I am/was 1 class short and that was 20 years ago.  It is something I am ashamed of.

At the age of 43 years, I sold everything I owned to go to medical school.  I wanted to change the way the world treats children with diabetes by educating the public.  Now I'm 63 years old, in debt, work 120 hours a week, and realize I never stopped to think that maybe the world doesn't want to learn or change.

Leaving a promising job (as a co-founder) at a start-up company to take a job at an older/larger company thinking I could change attitudes of employees to care about PE backers, EBITDA, performance metrics.  The company I left was a huge success with a 9-figure exit and the company I joined was sold for pennies after funding dried up.

I regret giving in too soon on having a child. I would have adopted, but knew that my his band's attitude would not have gotten us through the process. Before we got married he said he wanted a family and adoption was on the table
Not being more historically informed and civically engaged throughout my life.
I regret that I “settled” when I married. Twice. Finally got it right the third time.

I regret the way I treated social outcasts in public school because I was too insecure to go against the norm. Sometimes when people inferred the worst from my unclear communications, I let them believe it was the worst (ugliness, racism,  not being wanted etc.). I hope they are all doing okay now and that they don't give a second thinking about those moments.

I regret not being more pragmatic in my choice of spouses - 26 years later, it turns out that love isn't everything.  It's lots, but not everything. I should have held out for love AND a few more criteria.
I haven't had my own career.  It's all been about my family.

I have financial regret. I wish I had started budgeting earlier in life and been more aware of the financial impact of my choices sooner. The money I could have today makes me a bit sick to my stomach when I think about what I wasted.
I was the top student in a sales training course at my company, but at graduation, I asked for an account management job instead. I did that out of fear.

I regret not working less and being more present with my two sons when they were younger. Now they are teenagers and I wish I could go back to an afternoon where all they wanted was my time and attention.
Not taking bigger career-related risks when I was younger

I rarely look back so regrets are hard to recall! One is that I raced so quickly to be 'grown up' that I didn't know how to relax and enjoy the time I was in. Sexually, I tried to make up for a Catholic upbringing by diving in at university and from there it was 20+ years before I started to examine my life, my purpose, my meaning-filled activities. Which meant choosing the wrong men, repeatedly, even when I thought I'd figured things out.
Regret that I feared failure and turned down jobs that I did not feel I could succeed.

Never believing enough in my point of view as a professional psychologist to speak out and be public about it.   My dissertation was on the effects of different forms of relaxation training especially visualization on the autonomic nervous system and I think though flawed as all dissertations are, it had the seeds of something important but I never pursued it or made it public in anyway.    It comes from a lack of confidance in my own work and I am sorely regretful about that.   I also regret not having grandchildren although not so much about not having children.    Oh and I wish I had focused on the study of dreams, not as simply psychological constructs but as perhaps one of the most fascinating and poorly understood cognitive phenomenon.    I think they are one of the most remarkable and poorly researched human capacities.

I don't regret anything. Yes, there are many things I would have done differently in retrospect. But hindsight is 20/20. More importantly, every cell in my body is here now as a direct result of everything I have experienced in life up until this point. It's interesting to regret, as each of those lived experiences are who made me who "I am" in this moment. To change them would change who I am now, as those "regrettable" moments are formative to my very being now.
I wish I had valued my little brother more when we were young

I knocked over a bottle of lamp oil with my elbow while wrapping presents one December. It was a horrible chemical smell and we eventually called in professional cleaners (with even stronger chemicals) and replaced the carpet underlay. In January my son developed a severely debilitating, permanently life changing autoimmune neurological illness. For 25 years I’ve wondered... in that split second when it was falling off the couch, if I’d caught that bottle instead of watching it shatter-would that have been enough to not tip the balance on his immune system? To let him speak again, use a remote control again, choose his own life again?
Not working harder on making friends

I regret not being braver.  My sister died before I had the chance to speak with her about her wishes regarding her son.  I have lived with anger over what she did because she couldn't be honest with me and I could not have that difficult conversation with her as I did not want the final months of her life spent fighting with her sister.
I regret not traveling internationally when I was younger.
Not standing up for myself as my relationship crumbled
Making commitments to move forward with several key relationships that I knew in my heart were probably not right for me.  My instincts are usually correct, but I didn't listen to them enough.
I regret being too scared to communicate openly and honestly with my dad before he died. I also regret not writing about life when he was dying because now I hardly remember what happened.
being cruel or petty to people
I regret not believing in myself and loved ones in my young adulthood. I could have supported myself and those I love to be more, to do more, and to go so much farther had I just believed.
1.  Not serving my country in the military
Marrying the wrong person too young, before I had any idea who I was.
Didn't take a trip to China when I had the opportunity
blah blah blah bl
Wish I got more stories from my Dad while he was alive
I should have studied abroad in college but didn’t because I didn’t want to be away for a summer. It would have been an amazing experience and I could have done it.

A couple was in the process of adopting two boys from another country asked what they might expect, given that the babies had been abandoned, were infants, and early care was unknown, I responded too curtly.  I said that the children may well have learning and behavior problems.  Who can predict the future?
Going into education as a career. I was a first generation college student and there were teachers in my family so I did what I had been exposed to.
I regret putting so much emphasis on my career when my kids were young. Spending extra time working to advance my salary instead of spending that time with them when they were young.
Those times I couldn't find a positive in a tough situation. I made too many "surface" decisions.
Travelled when I was young. Started my own business.

Recent and current; not having the courage to leave my husband. Whimsy the feeling is intermittent, it's the biggest negative impact on my personal, social and professional life and at times borders on psychological abuse.
That I was not more open to new experiences and risk taking in my twenties; that I was too quick to embrace adulthood.
Not being choosy enough/having higher standards with my partner. Not being more deliberately considered about my career.

I regret allowing Imposter Syndrome and the fear of failure stop me from pursuing my own business. My head knows I can do it and be successful, but my heart needs a bit of work - it was battered at my previous workplace which was incredibly toxic and is still healing now. I'm working through the launch of my business now, but it's taking longer than it should.
Not studying overseas when I had the chance to do so. Specifically, I let the university’s process dictate my fate, and didn’t work harder to get there.
not buying a house earlier in life
I regret letting fear of failure stop me from trying new things in my life and only realizing in 60's that I can fail and the world will not end.
Not keeping my young family together.
Lacking patience
Failing to sufficiently show my grandmother my appreciation for her love for me before she passed away.
Not trying a career in industry before transitioning directly from undergraduate to graduate studies
Regret not living in the moment more
I regret not following my heart to be with someone I loved owing to familial and societal pressures.
Not seeking help and studying better when in college
Missing my grandmother's funeral in Indonesia because I was studying in Singapore and the funeral date coincided with my university exam in Singapore
Getting married to my ex-spouse.
Not telling people I love that I loved them, before I couldn’t.
Not being bold enough to pursue my own path overtly - I got real lucky that I'm in a great place professionally & personally - dumb luck helped more than courage
It's not knowing how much some of my words and actions hurt the people I love and care for.
Trying again with a relationship that I knew wasn't right for me but thinking love was enough. letting emotions cloud my judgement, and ending up hurting that person.
Haber trabajado en una empresa durante demasiados años. El jefe era muy manipulador

Una vez fuí muy duro con mi hija pequeña (2 años), mis dificultades personales y mi inexperiencia como padre me hicieron recriminarle lo que había hecho hasta que lloró. No se lo merecía y fui cruel sin una razón lógica.

When a relationship experiences a setback, it is the responsibility of both to reach out to each other to speak, clarify, and heal the harm. I regret those occasions where I have not found my way back, and I still feel angry with those when it has been them not finding the way back.

In college, I had a relationship with a girl that became very dysfunctional - I neglected relationships, my schoolwork, etc. - and affected me in a significant way for many years after the relationship ended. I regret getting so deep into this relationship.
A lo hecho pecho
Not spending more time with my mother to support her when she had hepatitis B.
No real regrets...I believe I took the correct decisions in the context I lived then
I regret I did not sell my stocks when the market was at its peak.
not to have divorced sooner
I missed out on the chance to live abroad and have unique life experiences.

I didn't travel to Paris by myself before I met my husband. I have an old boyfriend who lives there and it would have been a weeklong romantic but meaningless fling. A good tradeoff since I'd rather have my husband in the longterm, but sometimes I think about how magical it would have been and have a twinge of regret.
Getting a good picture with my mom on my wedding day.
After college, not trying to play volleyball professionally in Europe.

I regret that I did not understand that I could have set my sights higher, that I could have had personal standards which mattered, and that I was and am special in my abilities.  Didn't know it because I did not hear anyone telling me that!
I wish I would have had more sex partners when I was young- was too goody, goody.
Been more considerate in a few select instances,
I wish I got out of a bad relationship sooner.
Getting swindled by the psychic who eventually caused me to go bankrupt.
Thinking that I am my job.  I am not my job.
I regret spending more time at work than with family. While work brought me money and notoriety it took me away from those that mattered the most.

1. Not asking for career help sooner than age 40! Being afraid to network.  Not trying jobs on for "fit" and leaving when I realized it wasn't me it was them!   
2. Not going to an Eric Clapton concert when I had a single ticket for front row - as a young woman I was swayed to do something else by a boy who turned out to be quite dull.
Not keeping my daughter in a Montessori school past grade 1. Her education beyond that was abominable.
I wish I had had the wherewithal to respond to my dad when he asked me to.

I hate to say I have any regrets because I learned long ago not to...but if I HAD to list at least one, it would be that I sometimes regret my actions after I get angry, like yelling or feeling hate.  I almost didn’t take this survey because I have a hard time saying I regret anything I’ve done.  I may have made bad decisions but ultimately they made me who I am today and I love me!
I regret that I settled for less when it came to giving my heart away.  Short term gain, long term pain. I'm free now, so there is that consolation.
Eating disorder

I regret not telling my dear friend that I was hurt by her choice to leave me out of her wedding plans. My silence hurt our relationship more.
I regret taking an offer for work from my ex-mother-in-law. Not having a better work opportunity is NOT a good enough reason to invite ghosts from your past into your present. It was an emotional nightmare and hard to be professional.
I wish I had tried to figure out a way to go to law school when I had the chance.
That I didn’t know I could do a Broadcast journalism career with a communications degree. I feel I missed my calling.
Being less controlling to those around me especially my family

regretList.regret: From a young age and into adulthood, spending too much time, energy and head space worrying about boys and relationships, and letting a broken heart affect my life and identity too much.

regretList.regret: Sleeping with a friends boyfriend.

regretList.regret: I wish I had ignored my childhood dream and taken up an unexpected, completely different, career path when it was offered to me as I left university. Instead I stuck to an outdated idea of what I could be, and pursued an old dream, entering a profession I wasn't suited to and which I later failed at, leaving me with a life time's regret and feelings of being second-rate. It colours everything I've attempted since and leads me to  'repackage' my life story for anyone who asks about how I spent my 20s and 30s.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I regret how I handled a situation. It was cowardly.

regretList.regret: not starting my business earlier and moving to live in another country

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I regret having started smoking and then failing repeatedly for 30+ years to successful quit.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I wish I'd gone to couple's counselling with my previous partner before we split up, we had a special relationship and didn't do all we could to save it.

regretList.regret: Not saving the 'silly' bonuses I received when working with one particular business.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I wish I hadn’t pushed my apparently lazy daughter to do her homework. She learned to put too much pressure on herself. I wish I’d just let her find her own path.

regretList.regret: I lost my temper with my son when he was about eight years old.  He had been spitting on the floor, making his sister laugh.  I became so enraged that I hit him on the back.  Later when I was helping him change clothes, I noticed my hand print on his back.  I was beside myself with shame for hurting him, and seeing the reminder of my temper on his back.

I regret not trusting my instinct when my (now ex-) husband and (former) best friend didn't hide their flirting. Although I pressed each of them for many years to level with me if their friendship had become more than a friendship, they each emphatically denied it. Being a trusting person who loved both of them dearly, I foolishly believed them. Over the course of 7 years, the situation continued to eat at me until one Sunday evening when he finally answered "yes" to my question about whether they were sleeping together. It took another 6 years for him to finally agree to a divorce because he "didn't want to destroy the family." Fool that he is, that train had already left the station: two of my three kids have no relationship with their father because of the betrayal. I wish I had trusted my instinct and left him the first time I noticed their sexual energy.

I regret not leaving a job before they had me wrongfully arrested.  it seems after years of being overlooked for a promotion when I finally made branch manager, jealousy caused someone in the audit department to accuse me of stealing $5,000.  After the arrest and investigation by the police it was discovered that the fraud was done by a client and not me.  If they had just go one more step they would have seen the error.  But that's what it took to propel me into my own business, I never looked backed. Now 11 years later I am in awe of my success by God's grace but with all the signs to leave if I had leave sooner I would have been well ahead of where I am now. So my lesson when you see the signs that it's time to leave whether its a job or someone don't delay because the pain of staying is often times greater than the pain of leaving.

I was meeting with a new supervisor for the first time after my GREAT boss of 13 years left the company. There were major conflicts around goals with other departments, and despite all my intentions to be pleasant and take the high road when meeting with the new boss, I did the opposite and unleashed a torrent of all the bad things that were going on. It was ugly and not how I wanted to present myself or the organization. I left the meeting feeling terrible. Soon after, she gave me a horrible performance review, re-organized the department, fired a beloved colleague, and I rejected the "new" position they offered me and quit. It was all a terrible experience, but the thing I regret the most is NOT taking the high road in that meeting, for not having the savvy to know she had already been tasked with making significant changes. It would not have changed what happened, but I would have been able to have more pride in how I conducted myself with her.
